Collaborative Research: Characterizing Interactions of Carbon Dioxide with Tailored Adsorbing Materials for Capture of Carbon Dioxide from Power Plant Exhaust Gas and Ambient Air

Capturing CO2 from ambient air, or air capture, has significant technical challenges. The concentration of CO2 in air (~ 400 ppm) is far less than the CO2 concentrations in other applications such as post-combustion flue gas treatment. Any air capture process must use minimal amounts of energy, ideally from a distributed renewable source such as solar thermal energy. To apply air capture or conventional Carbon Capture Utilization and Storage (CCUS) on large scales, low cost and highly durable materials are required.

Tailored carbon dioxide adsorbents that combine nitrogen-bearing chemicals on solid sponge-like supports are perhaps the only class of adsorbents that might be practical for air capture applications. These materials are also important in CO2 removal from flue gases. These gas separation processes require a material to selectively removes CO2 (leaving other species behind) in the temperature range of 0-65 C, and in an environment where water is ubiquitous. Under these conditions, many types of adsorbents can be effectively ruled out. Some (physisorbents) will not effectively adsorb CO2 under these conditions because water competes with the carbon dioxide for sites within the material. Some other chemical types (chemisorbents) require high temperature operating conditions.

In contrast,the PIs propose to use supported amines to adsorb large volumes of CO2. The amines are also selective for CO2. Even when the carbon dioxide is fairly dilute, as in air, these materials are able to withdraw the carbon dioxide from the atmosphere. Thus, the proposed work here focuses on fundamental characterization of connections between CO2 and the specialized adsorbents, targeted towards conventional CCUS.

The purpose of the proposed work is to provide a comprehensive study of specialized solid amine adsorbents in cycles of carbon dioxide adsorption and desorption relevant to CO2 capture from industrial emissions like power plant flue gas and ambient air. The work will bring together traditional adsorption/desorption studies with structural characterization techniques applied to these materials, coupled with computational studies. A particularly innovative aspect will be the application of three different in-situ spectroscopic techniques, infrared, Raman, and nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy to probe the structure of the CO2 as it adsorbs to the surface of the specialized amine adsorbent.

A cost-effective technology that could capture carbon dioxide (CO2) from ambient air could minimize the problems associated with transporting large volumes of CO2 from point source emitters (e.g. coal-fired power plants) to sites suitable for geological sequestration. Unlike conventional Carbon Capture Utilization and Storage (CCUS) from large power plant exhaust gases, which can at best slow the rate of increase of the atmospheric CO2 concentration, direct air capture, if widely adopted, can reduce the atmospheric CO2 level. This technology can impact distributed emissions sources (e.g. vehicles) that are currently beyond the reach of carbon capture technologies. The fundamental scientific investigations will provide new insights that will impact a wide array of CO2 adsorption technologies, including post-combustion CO2 capture, the direct extraction of CO2 from ambient air, purification of natural gas streams, and adsorption of CO2 on similar nitrogen-bearing materials for catalysis.

The collaborative project engages scientists from two disciplines, (i) chemical and biomolecular engineering and (ii) chemistry and biochemistry, with student exchanges and collaboration fostering communication across the boundaries of science and engineering.

The project also has significant potential to impact groups that are historically under-represented in science and engineering. PIs will actively recruit under-represented students to take part in this research, engaging Georgia Tech programs such as the Summer Undergraduate Research in Engineering (SURE) program. Additionally, the Institute for School Partnership (ISP) at Washington University will engage secondary school teachers and teach them about CCUS.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our research has used the technique of solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy to characterize the reaction of carbon dioxide (CO2) as it chemically reacts with a porous solid, designed and synthesized for the capture of this gas.  What NMR is able to accomplish is to show:  a) what chemical structures are present, and b) in what quantity, even when the solid-state material is disordered (meaning non-crystalline in this case).

The system here is a porous silicate solid called “SBA15”, and it has been intentionally decorated with pendant molecules (called “amines”) that have nitrogen-groups present to react with the incoming carbon dioxide gas molecules—the assembly is referred to as a “solid amine sorbent”, shown schematically in Fig. 1.  When they interact, they create new chemical species—these form a new carbon-nitrogen bond and now become a new molecule that in effect “ties down” the CO2.  One of the desirable properties of these specialized solid amine sorbents is their ability to release the CO2 in a reaction that goes in reverse (see Fig. 2), usually by heating the sample.  In doing so, the CO2 can be captured and then released later for another application (such as enhanced oil recovery) or to use it as a commodity chemical.

With our NMR studies, we have found that two different carbon-nitrogen species are present, called a carbamate (see species B, Fig. 1) and a carbamic acid (species A).  We also can show that the synthesis of the SBA15 + pendant amines led to some new chemical pendants that were not predicted, called a di-tethered amine (species F, with two connections to the surface). 

Our NMR results demonstrated that we could use this spectroscopy to monitor the formation of these new carbon-nitrogen bonds.  Over time, we could also observe the reverse reaction and watch the release, with the carbamic acid (A) releasing the CO2 more rapidly than the carbamate (species B).

In sophisticated experiments with NMR, we were also able to sensitively measure the distance between carbon and nitrogen atoms.  These interactions can be mathematically modeled to account for whether one nitrogen is interacting with just one carbon, or if there are others in the vicinity (and vice versa).  From our results, we found that the carbamate/carbamic acid nitrogen (species A, B) interacts primarily with one carbon at a given distance.  However, when we observed the carbamate carbon (species B), it appears to interact with more than one nitrogen—one at a close distance, and one further away.  This result showed us that there is a second nitrogen-bearing species near the carbamate (species C)—and our model shows that a separate positively-charged nitrogen (called an “ammonium”) helps stabilize this interaction (species C, D).

Finally, several pieces of evidence pointed to the existence of an additional carbon species, a bicarbonate (species E).  Because bicarbonate (HCO3–) has no nitrogen present, we could not use the same suite of techniques, and instead applied multiple NMR methods to find ways to discern that it is present.  

These results are of critical importance to materials scientists and engineers who are creating custom-designed materials for the capture of carbon dioxide and other gases from flue gases, and potentially from other sources in the future, such as cars and trucks that also create CO2 as a byproduct from fossil fuel combustion.  Molecular-level details about the chemistry occurring on such surfaces is valuable, and the ability of NMR to sensitively quantify the species present and to evaluate the reactivity of molecules (and also to monitor their release) is unique.  Back in the 1980’s, materials were also designed to help eliminate SOx and NOx gases from flue gases, and we have seen such pollutants (as contributors to smog and acid rain) plummet ever since.  If we can do the same for carbon dioxide, that would help reduce the amount present in the atmosphere.

This project permitted partial support and training of a team of 4 graduate students, 2 undergraduate students, and 3 postdoctoral researchers.  Our ability to collaborate closely with a chemical engineering team at Georgia Institute of Technology (via co-PI's Chris Jones and Carsten Sievers) led to a higher-quality project, by learning about these materials in depth thorugh them.  A substantial portion of one Ph.D. thesis and a second Ph.D. thesis will result from this work.  We also have 5 publications either accepted or under review, with an additional 1-2 publications planned on results collected near the end of the project.  It's worthwhile to note, the PI (Sophia Hayes) was also selected to give a prestigious "Town Talk" in Telluride, CO to the general public on the subject of this work.
